channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-15572] Adding optional timestamp semantics to HBase-Spark
item.description:
Right now the timestamp is always latest. With this patch, users can select timestamps they want.
In this patch, 4 parameters, "timestamp", "minTimestamp", "maxiTimestamp" and "maxVersions" are added to HBaseSparkConf. Users can select a timestamp, they can also select a time range with minimum timestamp and maximum timestamp. A new test for selecting records with different timestamps is added.
item.summary: Adding optional timestamp semantics to HBase-Spark

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Please update to include a description. We don't accept jira without any actionable information.
Right now the timestamp is always latest. With this patch, users can select timestamps they want.

93	  val minStamp = parameters.get(HBaseRelation.MIN_STAMP).map(_.toLong)

94	  val maxStamp = parameters.get(HBaseRelation.MAX_STAMP).map(_.toLong)

MIN_STAMP -> MIN_TIMESTAMP
MAX_STAMP -> MAX_TIMESTAMP


243	      case _ => throw new IllegalArgumentException("Invalid combination of query/timestamp/time range provided")

Better include relation.timestamp, relation.minStamp, relation.maxStamp in the message.
Please open reviewboard for the review.
Yes, I have attached the link.
Thanks for the comments. I have updated the patch.

+  val MIN_TIMESTAMP = "minTimeStamp"

nit: 'S' can be lowercase - I can change it when I commit the patch.

-1 Ted Yu please do not commit before all feedback has been addressed.

Please update docs to explain the feature and usage.
I have reverted this from master, per my above request for docs.

Normally the docs mentioned above can be added to this JIRA after commit.

Now that the patch has been reverted, please re-commit when docs is added.
Please also note the reason for revert in the commit message.

Normally the docs mentioned above can be added to this JIRA after commit.

Not for a fundamental: the why and usage of a feature.

And besides, you cannot commit over the top of a reviewers request, ever.

Suggest you back off with the flash-commits. What is the hurry? It ends up just making more work all around.

The description is much better than previously. My request is for a description in the ref guide. That's the foundational layer for explaining to downstream folks how we expect them to use the features we create. There ought to be section already for hbase-spark, please add description / usage there.
Thanks. I have updated the patch.

I don't see any docs changes in v4. maybe missed adding it to git?

Weiqing Yang Can you please add a description in the ./src/main/asciidoc/_chapters/spark.adoc as requested.

Sean Busbey There is a document JIRA opened for the new Dataframe user interface and features. The PR is not sent yet, because currently there is still a number of place needed to be changed in the DataFrame support for HBase. Once it is done, a more complete doc will be sent for the community review. To make the work more trackable, I create a link for this jira to https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-14789.

HBASE-15473: Documentation for the usage of hbase dataframe user api (JSON, Avro, etc)

Thanks for the pointer Zhan Zhang. I've upgraded that jira to blocker. It would be much better to incorporate the need for documentation into the various jiras as incremental improvements.

Keeping it in a different jira makes it substantially harder to get in-progress Spark support into branch-1. I'll have to scope out how bad the gap is in the next couple of weeks so we can decide if hbase-spark will make it into the 1.3 release.
The patch also seems to have added MAX VERSION support. Don't miss it in the Description or the doc.
Sean BusbeyZhan ZhangJerry He Thanks for your feedback. I have updated the doc.
Sean Busbey The v5 is updated (spark.adoc). Thanks.

Looking forward to your review, Sean Busbey

Sean Busbey Hi, Sean
I tried to add descriptions in spark.adoc and submitted several times but failed, e.g. HBASE-15572-8.patch. HBASE-15572-7.patch is the version without doc update, which passed all the tests. The only difference between HBASE-15572-8.patch and HBASE-15572-7.patch as following:
------------------------
diff --git src/main/asciidoc/_chapters/spark.adoc src/main/asciidoc/_chapters/spark.adoc
index b1bdb5d..9148ce2 100644
— src/main/asciidoc/_chapters/spark.adoc
+++ src/main/asciidoc/_chapters/spark.adoc
@@ -395,6 +395,11 @@ The HBase-Spark module includes support for Spark SQL and DataFrames, which allo
you to write SparkSQL directly on HBase tables. In addition the HBase-Spark
will push down query filtering logic to HBase.

+Users can query records with different timestamps or time ranges with
+minimum timestamp and maximum timestamp. In HBaseSparkConf, the hbase configuration,
+four parameters related to timestamp can be set: timestamp, minTimestamp,
+maxiTimestamp and maxVersions.
+
---------------------
I am new to contribute the apache community. Could you please help to check if the error is from the test system itself or from my patch? I think my patch is small and safe which just add timestamps to let users select different timestamps or time ranges. Thank you very much for your help.

the unit test failures aren't related to your patch.

The text blurb is a good start, but a code example will make it clearer (as most of the other spark feature explanations do in the ref guide). Since this will involve more prose explaining the examples this should probably be a subsection rather than a standalone paragraph.

Looking at the patch and the existing examples I have a few additional questions:

  • As new constants in HBaseSparkConf, the names need to be scoped rather than bare as e.g. 'timestamp' should be 'hbase.spark.query.timestamp' (or something similar within the 'hbase.spark' prefix).
  • Does this only let folks choose timestamp ranges in SparkSQL? Or does it also work for the other HBase query mechanisms, like the hBaseRDD described in the Basic Spark section of the ref guide?

bq> Does this only let folks choose timestamp ranges in SparkSQL? Or does it also work for the other HBase query mechanisms, like the hBaseRDD described in the Basic Spark section of the ref guide?

I think they are only used for SparkSQL, to pass property option to SparkSQL and to data source class. hbaseRDD takes SCAN object, which would contains everything.

There is another question.

Instead of putting the timestamp range as option properties to the DF table, can we think about putting them as 'virtual' column in a way that they can appear in SQL statement.
For example, (select col1 from hbaseTable where rowkey = 1 and TIMESTAMP > 123345)

Thanks for the reply.
Yes, you are right. A code example will make it clear, so I will add more detailed description in HBASE-15473: Documentation for the usage of hbase dataframe user api (JSON, Avro, etc).
(1) I will submit v9 which renames ’timestamp’ to be “spark.hbase.query.timestamp”, as well as the other three parameters in SparkHBaseConf.
(2) This only used for SparkSQL.

Thanks for the feedback. That’s a good idea. However, it may cause potential troubles. For example, if a virtual column is put into the sql schema, users may have select timestamp from table. It is a valid query in sql, but not valid in Hbase, since this timestamp is implicit in Hbase attached to a row, there is really no such column in the Hbase row. We cannot construct a scan using this. Thus it is an invalid query for HBase.

(1) I will submit v9 which renames ’timestamp’ to be “spark.hbase.query.timestamp”, as well as the other three parameters in SparkHBaseConf.

Is there a reason this can't be "hbase.spark.query.timestamp" ?

Yes, you are right. A code example will make it clear, so I will add more detailed description in HBASE-15473: Documentation for the usage of hbase dataframe user api (JSON, Avro, etc).

I would like documentation complete as a part of adding this feature rather than as a follow on. Is there some reason we can't document this addition unless we also document the use of JSON, Avro, etc?

(1) The name follows the convention of existing HBaseSparkConf. But you are right, we may want to use hbase.spark instead of spark.hbase. I think it would be better to solve it with a separate JIRA to change all these names in one shot instead of introducing name inconsistency.
(2) Regarding the document JIRA, it does have some loose dependency, e.g., JSON format, etc, DataFrame Rread/Writer, etc. Otherwise, it is hard to explain the usage in a clear way. For Zhan Zhang has already created jira HBASE-15473, I think it is better to add more explanation on that jira.

(1) The name follows the convention of existing HBaseSparkConf. But you are right, we may want to use hbase.spark instead of spark.hbase. I think it would be better to solve it with a separate JIRA to change all these names in one shot instead of introducing name inconsistency.

There are already both "hbase.spark" and "spark.hbase" entries in HBaseSparkConf and a ticket for correcting the "spark.hbase" ones (HBASE-15597).

Please do not make the problem worse. Please correct your use of constant keys before this patch goes in. To be clear, I won't +1 this patch without either a technical justification for needing the "spark.hbase" version or correcting it.

(2) Regarding the document JIRA, it does have some loose dependency, e.g., JSON format, etc, DataFrame Rread/Writer, etc. Otherwise, it is hard to explain the usage in a clear way. For Zhan Zhang has already created jira HBASE-15473, I think it is better to add more explanation on that jira.

Your added test does not appear to rely on the currently undocumented additions, unless I'm missing it? If you like, we can make HBASE-15473 a blocker for this to make sure the prerequisites are in place?

the unit test failures aren't related. I added HBASE-15644 to stop checking scaladoc, since we haven't done any of the work related to that yet.

I'm +1 on v10. Will push later today unless someone else has feedback they want addressed.

Ted Yu are you still +1 on v10? If so I'll add an additional signed-off-by from you when I push.
Weiqing Yang, is there a particular email address you'd prefer be associated with this commit?
I would like yangweiqing001@gmail.com. Thanks.

For example, (select col1 from hbaseTable where rowkey = 1 and TIMESTAMP > 123345)

However, it may cause potential troubles. For example, if a virtual column is put into the sql schema, users may have select timestamp from table. It is a valid query in sql, but not valid in Hbase, since this timestamp is implicit in Hbase attached to a row, there is really no such column in the Hbase row. We cannot construct a scan using this. Thus it is an invalid query for HBase.

Selecting the timestamp from table (have it in projection) is tricky, but it could still be valid for advanced use case. Having it in predicates should anyway work.
This support is for SQL. Shouldn't we leverage more of the flexibility of SQL?
But it is probably for another discussion.

The patch looks good.

Thanks Weiqing for seeing this patch through!

In the future, please use `git format-patch` as described in the contribution guide when making patches, so it's easier to give you credit for your work.

Thanks to everyone for reviewing.
Yes, it is better to open another discussion. Thanks for your feedback, Jerry.
Sure, I will pay attention to the contribution guide next time. Thanks for all the help.

HBASE-15572 Adding optional timestamp semantics to HBase-Spark; ADDENDUM (stack: rev 36e4033dedfa3bf4f9ac5de35bb1c46334aa74c0)

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue:
Right now the timestamp is always latest. With this patch, users can select timestamps they want.
In this patch, 4 parameters, "timestamp", "minTimestamp", "maxiTimestamp" and "maxVersions" are added to HBaseSparkConf. Users can select a timestamp, they can also select a time range with minimum timestamp and maximum timestamp.
